title: Time Series
text:
By: Maria Agustina Zuckerberg


What is a Time Series ?

Any metric that is measured over regular time intervals makes a Time Series. A time series is a sequence of data points or observations collected or recorded over a period of time at specific, equally spaced intervals. Each data point in a time series is associated with a particular timestamp or time period, making it possible to analyze and study how a particular variable or phenomenon changes over time. Time series data can be found in various domains and can represent a wide range of phenomena, including financial data, economic indicators, weather measurements, stock prices, sales figures, and more.

Example: Weather data, Stock prices, Industry forecasts, etc are some of the common ones.

The analysis of experimental data that have been observed at different points in time leads to new and unique problems in statistical modeling and inference.
The obvious correlation introduced by the sampling of adjacent points in time can severely restrict the applicability of the many conventional statistical methods traditionally dependent on the assumption that these adjacent observations are independent and identically distributed.

Key characteristics of time series data include:
Temporal Order: Time series data is ordered chronologically, with each data point representing an observation at a specific point in time. The order of data points is critical for understanding trends and patterns over time.
Equally Spaced Intervals: In most cases, time series data is collected at regular intervals, such as hourly, daily, weekly, monthly, or yearly. However, irregularly spaced time series data can also exist.
Dependency: Time series data often exhibits temporal dependency, meaning that the value at a given time is influenced by or related to the values at previous times. This dependency can take various forms, including trends, seasonality. This serial correlation is called as autocorrelation.
Components: Time series data can typically be decomposed into various components, including:
Trend: The long-term movement or direction in the data. Seasonality: Repeating patterns or cycles that occur at fixed intervals. Noise/Irregularity: Random fluctuations or variability in the data that cannot be attributed to the trend or seasonality.
Applications: Time series data is widely used for various applications, including forecasting future values, identifying patterns and anomalies, understanding underlying trends, and making informed decisions based on historical data.
Analyzing time series data involves techniques like time series decomposition, smoothing, statistical modeling, and forecasting. This class will cover but not be limited to traditional time series modeling including ARIMA, SARIMA, the multivariate Time Series modeling including; ARIMAX, SARIMAX, and VAR models, Financial Time Series modeling including; ARCH, GARCH models, and E-GARCH, M-GARCH..ect, Bayesian structural time series (BSTS) models, Spectral Analysis and Deep Learning Techniques for Time Series. Researchers and analysts use software tools like Python, R, and specialized time series libraries to work with and analyze time series data effectively.
Time series analysis is essential in fields such as finance, economics, epidemiology, environmental science, engineering, and many others, as it provides insights into how variables change over time and allows for the development of predictive models to forecast future trends and outcomes.

title: Introduction
text:
Changes in oil prices have significant macroeconomic effects on countries and the global economy as a whole. The impact of oil price changes on macroeconomic variables depends on whether oil prices are rising or falling, and on the magnitude and persistence of the price change. Why does it have a significant impact?
Central banks may also respond to inflationary pressures from higher oil prices by adjusting interest rates. Changes in oil prices can affect exchange rates. Oil-exporting countries may see their currencies strengthen with higher oil prices, while oil-importing countries may see their currencies weaken.
Higher oil prices can act as a drag on economic growth, particularly for countries that are net oil importers, potentially slowing down economic activity. Countries that are net oil exporters can benefit from rising oil prices by earning more revenue from oil exports, thereby improving their trade balance.
There are voluntary, explicit decisions that change the price of oil and, on occasionally, exogenous events that cause a significant change in the price of oil.
Geopolitical events and oil supply disruptions can lead to sudden and significant oil price spikes, which can have unpredictable effects on macroeconomic stability and global security.
Economic models and analysis are often used to assess and predict the potential macroeconomic volatility associated with oil price fluctuations.
It is important to develop a time series model based on historical data and events in order to predict possible future scenarios and thus anticipate the necessary measures to be implemented. This will lead to greater economic and social stability.



How has the distribution of total global oil production among the main oil-producing countries evolved over the past two decades?
How do voluntary decisions made by organizations like OPEC (Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries), such as production cuts or increases, influence fluctuations in global oil prices?
How do exogenous factors and events influence the volatility and trends in global oil prices?
How have the US macroeconomic indicators, such as inflation rate, interest rates variation and currency exchange rate, responded to oil price shocks over the past years?
How have fluctuations in U.S. macroeconomic indicators influenced the global oil price over the past years?
How do fluctuations in oil prices impact stock market performance, such as energy, transportation, and staples sectors?
To what extent do variations in oil prices affect investor preferences for specific sectors, and how do they influence in stock market trends?
How do changes in oil prices affect consumersâ€™ attitudes and behaviors regarding personal finance, including spending and saving decisions?
How can time series analysis of historical oil price data be used to develop short-term and long-term forecasts of oil price fluctuations?
To what extent can the adoption of renewable energies and the reduction of exposure to fossil fuel price fluctuations contribute to improving economic stability?

title: Introduction
text:
Big Picture
Petroleum and its derivatives are an essential raw material in almost every manufacturing process. Since there are currently no substitutes available in sufficient quantities, their price is a determining factor in the cost structure of the final products. Therefore, any significant change in price has a direct impact on the real economy. This forces governments to make decisions to mitigate potential negative effects by adjusting public economic policies.
When oil prices rise, consumers may reduce their spending on other goods and services due to higher energy costs. Consumer confidence may also be adversely affected, thereby affecting spending patterns.
Higher oil prices increase production costs for businesses, potentially reducing their profit margins. This may lead to reduced business investment, particularly in energy-intensive industries.
Rising oil prices may encourage investment in the energy sector, including exploration and production. Conversely, falling oil prices may lead to reduced investment in the energy sector, affecting employment and economic activity in related industries.

title: Introduction
text:
Literature Review
A clear example of a voluntary decision is when OPEC (Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries) decides to reduce the volume of production with the intention of causing an increase in the price of oil and its derivatives.
A geopolitical event, such as Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine, where a unilateral decision by Russia not to supply oil and gas to the member countries of the European Union, creates a potential shortage, causing the price of oil to rise.
The current situation continues to put inflationary pressure on the US economy, forcing the government to monitor the inflation rate, continue the process of raising the interest rates, in order to strengthen its currency and make oil imports cheaper. In this context, the U.S. and the European Union are obliged to accelerate the process of replacing the use of fossil fuels with renewable, environmentally friendly energy, thus generating less dependence on oil.

Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc (TMO)
UnitedHealth Group Inc (UNH)







 The above visualization shows the stock prices of 6 global healthcare companies. The data shown is from the years 2018 to 2022. It can be observed that the tickers have a very different performance. First of all, it can be seen that TMO, UNH, LLY and JNJ had an overall positive trend over the last 5 years. In the case of NVS and PFE there are no strong patterns, so it can be said that the time series are stationary. This is due to the scale used on the y-axis. If we zoom in on the last two cases, NVS can be considered irregular because the prices have fluctuated without strong patterns, and PFE although it has a positive trend, it has fluctuated throughout the years.
